name: King Cobra
description: The world's longest venomous snake. Found in forests from India through Southeast Asia. Avoids humans but aggressive if cornered. Venom is neurotoxic and cardiotoxic.
symptoms: Severe pain, blurred vision, vertigo, drowsiness, paralysis. Death can occur within 30 minutes due to respiratory failure.
treatment: Immediate medical attention. Pressure immobilization bandage. Antivenom is essential.

name: Banded Krait
description: Easily identified by alternate black and yellow bands. Nocturnal and shy. Venom is neurotoxic.
symptoms: Minimal local pain, but progressive paralysis, respiratory failure. 'Sleeping sickness' where victims don't wake up.
treatment: Antivenom. Mechanical ventilation may be required.

name: Russell's Viper
description: Responsible for most snakebite incidents in India/SE Asia. Loud hissing warning. Hemotoxic venom.
symptoms: Pain, swelling, bleeding from gums/urine, kidney failure, necrosis.
treatment: Polyvalent antivenom. Dialysis for kidney failure.

name: Cobalt Blue Tarantula
description: Striking blue legs. Fast and aggressive. Lives in burrows in Thailand/Myanmar.
symptoms: Severe pain, muscle cramping, inflammation. Not usually fatal to healthy adults but debilitating.
treatment: Pain management, muscle relaxants. Clean wound to prevent infection.

name: Rosary Pea
description: Vine with attractive red and black seeds. Seeds contain abrin, one of the most toxic substances known.
symptoms: If chewed: nausea, vomiting, convulsions, liver failure, death. Swallowed whole seeds may pass harmlessly.

name: Suicide Tree
description: Fruit looks like a mango. Kernels contain cerberin, a cardiac glycoside.
treatment: Similar to digoxin poisoning. Atropine, monitoring.

name: Stinging Tree
description: Found in Australia/Indonesia rainforests. Covered in silicon-tipped hairs containing neurotoxin.
symptoms: Excruciating pain lasting days to months. 'Like being burnt with hot acid and electrocuted at the same time'.
treatment: Do not rub. Remove hairs with wax strip. Diluted hydrochloric acid soak (medical supervision).
